title: The New Kid in Robotics Club

chapters.text: Jake stood frozen in the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. The room buzzed with the sounds of small motors and excited chatter that instantly died when he appeared. A tall girl with purple-streaked hair looked him up and down. "Can we help you?" she asked, raising an eyebrow. Jake had just moved to town last week, and his mom insisted he join a club to make friends. He spotted a familiar face – Tyler from math class – who quickly looked away and whispered something to the boy next to him. They both snickered. Jake recognized that look. At his old school, Tyler had been his best friend until he suddenly wasn't. The robotics teacher waved him in with a smile. "Everyone, this is Jake! He'll be joining us this semester."

Jake stood frozen in the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. "He'll be joining us this semester," announced Ms. Chen, the club advisor, with a warm smile. Jake took a deep breath and stepped forward, scanning the room filled with circuit boards, wires, and half-built robots. A tall boy with curly hair waved him over to an empty seat at a table covered with robot parts. "I'm Theo," the boy said, sliding a small metal box toward Jake. "We need help with this motor assembly." Jake set his backpack down and picked up the tiny screwdriver on the table. His hands shook a little, but as he began working on the motor, the stares from the other students turned back to their own projects. Maybe this wouldn't be so bad after all.

Jake took a deep breath and stepped further into the robotics club room. The other students returned to their projects, the awkward moment passing. A tall girl with curly hair waved him over to an empty seat at her table. "I'm Mia," she said, showing him a small robot she was building. Jake noticed a blue ribbon pinned to the bulletin board with Mia's name on it. She had won first place at last year's science fair with her robot design. As Jake unpacked his notebook, he spotted an unusual metal piece shaped like a crown on the table. "That's part of our competition robot," Mia explained. "We need help programming it." She handed Jake a controller, and for the first time since moving to this new school, he felt a smile spread across his face. The robotics club might become his favorite place.

Jake relaxed his grip on his backpack as a tall girl with curly hair approached him. "I'm Mia, the club president," she said with a friendly smile. "Want to see what we're working on?" Jake nodded and followed her through the room where students huddled around tables covered with robot parts, wires, and tools. Some robots zoomed across the floor while others had mechanical arms that picked up small objects. A shiny silver robot in the corner wore a protective HELMET as it navigated an obstacle course. "We have competitions every month," Mia explained, showing Jake a trophy cabinet filled with awards. "You can join any team or start your own project." For the first time since moving to this new school, Jake felt excitement bubble up inside him. The clicking sounds of gears, the buzz of motors, and the focused energy of everyone working together made Jake certain the robotics club might become his favorite place.

A tall girl with curly hair waved him over to her workstation where a small robot arm attempted to stack colored blocks. "I'm Mia, team captain," she said with a friendly smile. "Want to help?" Jake nodded eagerly and set his backpack down beside the table. His nervousness melted away as Mia showed him how to adjust the robot's grip strength. When Jake successfully programmed the arm to pick up a blue cube, the whole table cheered. Even Mr. Peterson, the club advisor, came over to see Jake's work and gave him an approving nod. For the first time since moving to this new school, Jake felt like he belonged somewhere.

Jake's shoulders relaxed as he scanned the room filled with circuit boards, tools, and half-built robots. A tall girl with curly hair waved him over to an empty seat beside her workstation. "I'm Mia, team captain," she said, showing him a small robot that moved like a bug. "Want to help?" Jake nodded eagerly and set down his backpack. The other students returned to their projects, the initial awkwardness fading away. Soon Jake was connecting wires and testing motors while Mia explained their upcoming competition. The afternoon flew by as he worked alongside his new teammates, asking questions and offering suggestions that made even the eighth graders nod with approval. When the final bell rang, Jake was surprised by how quickly time had passed. As everyone packed up, Mia handed him a club schedule. "See you tomorrow?" she asked. Jake smiled and nodded, already planning improvements for their robot.

Jake smiled and nodded, already planning improvements for their robot. Over the next few weeks, he became a key member of the robotics club, sharing his ideas and working late after school with his new friends. Their robot, which they named "Sparky," won first place at the regional competition thanks to Jake's clever programming. On the celebration day, the team surprised him with a custom robotics kit and a card signed by everyone. Ms. Chen, their advisor, announced that Jake would be team captain next year. As he looked around at the smiling faces of his teammates, Jake couldn't believe how much had changed since that nervous first day. What had once been the scariest doorway in school had become his favorite place to be. The robotics club wasn't just about building machines—it had built something even better: a place where Jake finally belonged.
